title: Sync Engine: Multi-Device Synchronization with Offline-First Support

# Sync Engine Epic (GitHub Issue #54)

## Executive Summary

Design and implement a sync engine for Scribe, enabling multi-device synchronization with offline-first support. This lays the groundwork for a future mobile client.

---

## Strategic Goals

### Primary Goals
1. **Offline-first**: Users can edit notes without connectivity; changes sync when back online
2. **Multi-device**: Same vault accessible from desktop (now) and mobile (future)
3. **Real-time**: Changes propagate quickly when online (polling every 30s for v1)
4. **Conflict handling**: Concurrent edits to the same note don't lose data
5. **Opt-in & disableable**: Sync MUST be disabled by default and easily toggled off
6. **Data ownership**: Architecture should support future self-hosting option

### Why This Matters for Scribe
- Users expect their notes to be available everywhere
- Mobile is the most requested feature - sync is the foundation
- Offline-first respects user autonomy and works in any network condition
- Enterprise/corporate users need explicit opt-in for data governance

---

## Architectural Decisions (Pre-Made)

### 1. Sync Model
- **Client-server** topology with central server as source of truth
- **Document-level sync** (v1): Each note syncs as a whole JSON blob
- **Optimistic concurrency**: baseVersion comparison for conflict detection

### 2. Versioning Scheme
Two-tier versioning:
- `note.sync.version`: Per-note monotonic counter for conflict detection
- `serverSequence`: Global server sequence for efficient pull ("give me changes since X")

### 3. Storage Locations
- **Sync Database**: `{vault}/derived/sync.sqlite3` (follows derived data pattern)
- **Sync Config**: `{vault}/.scribe/sync.json` (vault-level, not app-level)
- **Package**: `packages/engine-sync/` (follows engine-* naming convention)

### 4. Authentication (v1)
- Simple API key with PBKDF2 hash
- Workers-compatible (no bcrypt native bindings)
- OAuth can be added later as alternative login method

### 5. Infrastructure
- Cloudflare Workers + D1 (SQLite at edge) + KV (session cache)
- R2 for future blob storage (attachments/images)

### 6. Tasks Handling
- Tasks (`vault/derived/tasks.jsonl`) are NOT synced
- Re-derived on each device from synced notes via TaskIndex
- Avoids data duplication and consistency issues

### 7. Conflict Resolution
- Store conflicts for user resolution (no auto-merge in v1)
- Three options: Keep Mine, Keep Theirs, Keep Both
- Side-by-side comparison view (read-only)
- Delete vs Edit conflicts handled specially

### 8. Tombstone TTL
- 90 days for deleted notes
- Notes deleted while a device is offline >90 days will reappear as "restored"
- Acceptable tradeoff, documented in UI

---

## Integration Points

### Existing Systems to Extend
1. **BaseNote interface**: Add `sync?: SyncMetadata` field
2. **EngineOrchestrator**: Add syncEngine integration, queue changes after save
3. **HandlerDependencies**: Add `syncEngine: SyncEngine | null`
4. **IPC Contract**: Add sync channels and SyncAPI interface
5. **EngineName type**: Add 'sync' to the union
6. **ErrorCode enum**: Add sync-specific error codes

### New Systems to Create
1. **packages/engine-sync/**: Client-side sync engine
2. **apps/sync-server/**: Cloudflare Workers server
3. **Sync UI components**: Status indicator, conflict modal, settings panel

---

## v1 Scope

### INCLUDED
- Document-level sync (whole note as unit)
- HTTP polling (30s interval when online)
- Push/pull REST endpoints
- Cloudflare Workers + D1 + KV infrastructure
- API key authentication (PBKDF2)
- Offline queue with exponential backoff retry
- Conflict detection & storage
- Basic resolution UI (keep mine/theirs/both)
- Side-by-side comparison (read-only)
- Delete vs edit conflict handling
- Type-specific sync (DailyNote, MeetingNote reference validation)
- Migration strategy for existing vaults
- Network detection and reconnect sync
- IPC contract extension
- Progress UI for initial sync

### DEFERRED (Post-v1)
- Attachment/image sync (requires R2 integration)
- WebSocket real-time push (reduces polling)
- Block-level CRDT merge (complex, different architecture)
- Auto-merge for DailyNotes (requires semantic understanding)
- Inline diff highlighting (nice-to-have)
- Manual merge editor (complex UI)
- OAuth authentication (Google, GitHub, etc.)
- End-to-end encryption (requires key management)
- Self-hosting option (config + docs)
- Shared/collaborative vaults (different sync model)
- Real-time collaboration (OT/CRDT, different problem)

---

## Phase Overview

### Phase 0: Opt-in Guards (CRITICAL - First)
Ensure sync is disabled by default and no network calls occur when disabled.
This protects enterprise/corporate users with data governance requirements.

### Phase 1: Core Infrastructure
Create the `packages/engine-sync/` package with core types, database, and engine interface.
This is the foundation that everything else builds on.

### Phase 2: Client Integration
Integrate SyncEngine with EngineOrchestrator, IPC handlers, and main process.
Connect the sync engine to the existing Scribe architecture.

### Phase 3: Server
Create `apps/sync-server/` with Cloudflare Workers, D1 database, and push/pull endpoints.
Build the cloud infrastructure that handles synchronization.

### Phase 4: UI
Build the user-facing sync components: status indicator, conflict resolution, settings.
Make sync visible and controllable for users.

### Phase 5: Testing & Polish
Comprehensive testing of sync flows, conflict resolution, and edge cases.
Ensure the feature is production-ready.

---

## Dependency Graph Summary

```
Phase 0 (Opt-in Guards)
    └── Phase 1 (Core Infrastructure)
            ├── Phase 2 (Client Integration)
            │       └── Phase 4 (UI)
            │               └── Phase 5 (Testing)
            └── Phase 3 (Server)
                    └── Phase 5 (Testing)
```

Phase 1 subtasks have internal dependencies (types before implementations).
Phases 2 and 3 can be developed in parallel after Phase 1.
Phase 4 and 5 require both client and server work to be complete.

---

## Success Criteria

1. **Opt-in works**: Fresh install has sync disabled, no network calls occur
2. **Enable flow works**: User can enable sync, create account, initial sync completes
3. **Edit flow works**: Changes sync within 30s, visible on second device
4. **Conflict handling works**: Concurrent edits detected, user can resolve
5. **Offline works**: Changes queue locally, sync when back online
6. **Type-specific works**: DailyNotes, MeetingNotes sync with reference validation
7. **Migration works**: Existing vaults can enable sync, all notes upload
8. **Disable works**: User can disable sync, no more network calls, data stays local

---

## Related Future Work

- Mobile client (iOS/Android) - shares engine-sync package
- Web client - shares engine-sync package (uses sql.js instead of better-sqlite3)
- End-to-end encryption - separate feature flag
- Shared vaults / collaboration - different sync model required

# Replace Console Usage in useVaultPath.ts

## Problem Statement
`apps/desktop/renderer/src/hooks/useVaultPath.ts` contains 4 instances of `console.*` that should use the structured logger from `@scribe/shared`.

## Why This Matters

### Production Visibility
Console logs in production:
- Are not captured by Electron's crash reporting
- Have no log levels (can't filter debug vs error)
- Are lost when the app closes
- Don't include structured context

### Debugging Difficulty
Without structured logging:
- Can't filter by severity
- Can't add context (vault path, user action)
- Can't aggregate across sessions

## Current Console Usage

```typescript
// apps/desktop/renderer/src/hooks/useVaultPath.ts
console.log('Loading vault path...');           // Line ~X
console.error('Failed to load vault:', err);    // Line ~Y
console.warn('Vault path not found');           // Line ~Z
console.debug('Vault path resolved:', path);    // Line ~W
```

## Target Implementation

```typescript
import { createLogger } from '@scribe/shared';

const log = createLogger('useVaultPath');

// Replace console.log with log.info or log.debug
log.debug('Loading vault path...');

// Replace console.error with log.error (includes stack trace)
log.error('Failed to load vault', { error: err.message, stack: err.stack });

// Replace console.warn with log.warn
log.warn('Vault path not found', { defaultPath: defaultVaultPath });

// Replace console.debug with log.debug
log.debug('Vault path resolved', { path });
```

### Step 1: Add Logger Import

import { createLogger } from '@scribe/shared';

const log = createLogger('useVaultPath');

Map console methods to logger methods:

| `console.error` | `log.error` | Add error context |

log.error('Vault load failed', {

});

# Document Intentional Swallowed Promises

## Problem Statement
The codebase has 7 instances of `.catch(() => {})` or `.catch(() => ...)` that intentionally swallow promise rejections. While intentional, they lack explanatory comments.

## Why This Matters

### Code Review Friction
Without comments, reviewers may think these are bugs:
- "Why is this error ignored?"
- "Shouldn't we handle this?"

### Future Maintenance
Developers maintaining this code need to understand:
- Why the error is intentionally ignored
- What the expected failure scenarios are

## Verified Instances (Accurate as of analysis)

| File | Line | Purpose |
|------|------|---------|
| `apps/cli/src/signals.ts` | ~93 | Signal cleanup - can fail if process exiting |
| `apps/cli/src/signals.ts` | ~106 | Second signal cleanup attempt |

Replace:
```typescript
cleanup().catch(() => {});
```

// Expected to fail if directory already removed or process terminating.

});

## Problem Statement
The `NoteHeader` component in `apps/desktop/renderer/src/components/NoteHeader/NoteHeader.tsx` (lines 27-46) contains local date formatting and **parsing** implementations.

## ⚠️ IMPORTANT: This is NOT a Simple Dedup

Unlike the CLI tasks, NoteHeader uses **date-fns parsing**:

```typescript

function formatDateString(dateStr: string): string {
  const date = parse(dateStr, 'MM-dd-yyyy', new Date());
  return date.toLocaleDateString('en-US', { ... });
}
```

This is fundamentally different from the CLI duplicates because:
1. It takes a **string in MM-dd-yyyy format**, not a Date object
2. It uses date-fns `parse()` to convert the string to a Date
3. The shared `formatDate` functions take Date objects, not formatted strings

import { parse } from 'date-fns';

  return formatDate(date, 'short'); // Use shared for formatting only

export function parseDateString(dateStr: string, format: string): Date { ... }

description:
# Settings Page Epic

## Overview
This epic implements a comprehensive Settings page for the Scribe desktop application, accessible via a gear icon in the sidebar footer. The settings page opens as a full-screen modal with a VS Code/macOS System Settings-style sidebar navigation pattern.

## Background & Motivation
Currently, Scribe has limited configurability exposed to users:
- Theme toggle is buried in the sidebar footer
- Vault location is hardcoded/undiscoverable
- Update checking requires manual intervention
- No centralized place for user preferences

A proper Settings page serves several goals:
1. **Discoverability** - Users can find and modify all app preferences in one place
2. **Professional UX** - Aligns with user expectations from VS Code, macOS, and modern Electron apps
3. **Foundation for Growth** - Establishes patterns for future settings (CLI, spellcheck, plugins, etc.)
4. **Vault Management** - Critical for users with multiple vaults or who need to relocate their data

## Architecture Decision: Full-Screen Modal Pattern
We chose a full-screen modal (hiding the sidebar) rather than:
- **Inline panel**: Would compete with editor space, complex state management
- **Separate window**: Electron multi-window adds complexity, feels disconnected
- **Route-based**: Would require router setup, loses context of current session

The full-screen modal pattern:
- Familiar from macOS System Preferences, VS Code Settings
- Clear entry/exit points (gear icon → modal → X/Escape)
- Can reuse existing Overlay primitive for backdrop and escape handling
- Sidebar navigation scales well as settings sections grow

## Technical Approach

### Phase 1: Infrastructure (Foundation)
Build reusable primitives and IPC infrastructure that enable the feature:
1. **SegmentedControl** - New design system primitive for theme picker
2. **Folder Picker IPC** - dialog:selectFolder for vault management
3. **Vault IPC Channels** - vault:getPath, vault:setPath, vault:create

### Phase 2: UI Shell (Scaffolding)
Build the settings page structure without full functionality:
1. **Sidebar gear icon** - Replace footer with settings trigger
2. **SettingsPage modal** - Full-screen container with sidebar layout
3. **Section navigation** - General and Changelog sections

### Phase 3: Settings Functionality (Features)
Implement actual settings with full behavior:
1. **Theme setting** - SegmentedControl with immediate apply
2. **Version + Updates** - Display version, check/install updates
3. **Vault display** - Show current path (read-only initially)
4. **Vault switching** - Full hot-reload implementation
5. **Create new vault** - initializeVault integration

## Key Technical Challenges

### Engine Hot-Reload (Most Complex)
Switching vaults at runtime requires:
- Proper cleanup of existing FileSystemVault instance
- Re-initialization of SearchEngine, GraphEngine, TaskEngine
- Renderer state refresh (note list, current note, etc.)
- Graceful handling of "current note doesn't exist in new vault"

**Mitigation**: We'll implement vault switching in waves:
1. First: Display current path (read-only)
2. Second: Full switching with engine hot-reload
3. Fallback: If hot-reload proves too risky, require app restart

### State Synchronization
Settings changes need to:
- Persist to config.json (already exists via app:setConfig)
- Reflect immediately in UI (theme, vault)
- Handle errors gracefully (invalid vault, failed update)

## Success Criteria
1. Gear icon visible in sidebar footer, clickable to open settings
2. Settings modal opens full-screen, closes via X or Escape
3. Theme switching works immediately with Dark/Light/System options
4. Version displayed, update checking functional
5. Vault path displayed, switching to valid vaults works
6. Create new vault initializes structure correctly

## Out of Scope (Future Work)
- CLI installation from Settings (separate feature)
- Actual changelog content (placeholder only)
- Keyboard shortcuts customization
- Plugin management
- Multiple simultaneous vaults

## References
- GitHub Issue: #50
- Existing IPC contract: packages/shared/src/ipc-contract.ts
- Theme system: packages/design-system/src/ThemeProvider.tsx
- Update hooks: apps/desktop/renderer/src/hooks/useUpdateStatus.ts
- Vault utilities: packages/storage-fs/src/vault.ts

## Dependency Graph Summary

Wave 2 (Depends on Wave 1): SettingsPage shell, Theme setting
Wave 3 (Depends on Wave 2): Version/Update section, Vault display

# Create SegmentedControl Design System Primitive

## What
Build a new reusable SegmentedControl component for the design system. This is a mutually exclusive toggle group (like iOS segmented controls or radio button groups styled as connected buttons).

## Why
- **Required for Theme Picker**: The Settings page needs Dark | Light | System options displayed as a segmented control per the spec
- **Design System Gap**: No existing component handles this pattern
- **Reusability**: This pattern will be useful elsewhere (view toggles, filter switches, etc.)

## Technical Approach

### Component API
```typescript
interface SegmentedControlProps<T extends string> {
  options: Array<{ value: T; label: string; disabled?: boolean }>;
  value: T;
  onChange: (value: T) => void;
  size?: 'sm' | 'md' | 'lg';
  fullWidth?: boolean;
  disabled?: boolean;
  'aria-label'?: string;
}
```

### Styling Requirements
- Connected buttons with shared border (first/last have rounded corners)
- Active segment has distinct background (accent color or elevated surface)
- Smooth transition between states (use vars.animation.duration.fast)
- Keyboard navigation: arrow keys to move between options
- Focus visible state on the entire group and active segment

- `vars.color.surface` - Inactive segment background
- `vars.color.accent` or `vars.color.backgroundAlt` - Active segment
- `vars.color.border` - Shared border between segments
- `vars.radius.md` - Corner radius for first/last segments

### Accessibility
- Role: `radiogroup` on container

- Keyboard: Arrow keys navigate, Enter/Space select
